Ladies and gentlemen, the response "yeah I guess so. Did you know women can play too?" is undeniably engaging. It is an unexpected response that takes the conversation in a new direction. It is a response that challenges common stereotypes and misconceptions about football. It is a response that is likely to spark curiosity and interest in the listener. 

I anticipate that the con side may argue that the response is not relevant to the conversation at hand. However, I would like to point out that the fact provided concerns the eligibility of female players in the NFL. Therefore, the response is directly related to the topic at hand. 

Furthermore, the response is likely to promote a healthy and inclusive discussion about gender equality in sports. It may even inspire the listener to research more about the topic and become more informed. 

In conclusion, the response "yeah I guess so. Did you know women can play too?" is a highly engaging response that adds value to the conversation. It is relevant, thought-provoking, and inclusive. Thank you.

Firstly, the response does not add any new information or perspective to the conversation. The fact that women can play in the NFL is already established, and the response merely reiterates this fact without providing any further insight or analysis. 

Secondly, the response does not contribute to the flow of the conversation. It interrupts the natural progression of the dialogue and may even be perceived as a non-sequitur. 

Lastly, the response may even come across as patronizing or condescending to the person who initiated the conversation. It implies that the speaker is not aware of basic facts about football, which can be discouraging and off-putting. 

In conclusion, the response "yeah I guess so. Did you know women can play too?" is not engaging. It adds nothing new to the conversation, interrupts the flow, and may even be perceived as condescending. Thank you.

In conclusion, the response "yeah I guess so. Did you know women can play too?" is engaging. It challenges stereotypes, provides a new perspective, and promotes inclusivity. Thank you.

topic_chat_history:
hi , do you watch football ? 
 a bit but not regularly . i did see the beginning of the superbowl a few weeks ago , but i only have a passing knowledge of football 
 i see . do you know who reggie miller is ? 
 do you mean the basketball player on the hall of fame ? otherwise , i do n't know a reggie miller in football 
 i meant to say alex smith , not sure why i was thinking of reggie . 
 i do n't know much but i think he was a quarterback . correct me if i 'm wrong 
 yeah he is and he was so good in school he wrapped up a college degree in two years 
 wow he must be brilliant or a very hard worker . i like quarterbacks since they lead the offense . 
 that is true . i think it is a bit of both . he took many ap tests , that 's why 
 while i do n't know much about alex , i tend to follow players like kellan moore who is the only left handed quarterback in the nfl 
 that is amazing , amongst so many players he is the only one 
 i mean i know it is inherently harder if you are left handed as a qb 
 yeah . and baker mayfield once considered quitting to become a competitive gamer 
 i also think brady johnson is impressive as well since he has even thrown a touchdown pass to himself 
 that i would like to see . do you know who created the circular huddle ? 
 i do n't know his name , but i think he was deaf right ? what is his name ? 
 yeah he was deaf . his name was paul hubbard 
 in any case , i like following players like tom brady , brady jonson , and etc
topic_chat_fact: the nfl has no written rule against female players ; women would in fact be allowed if they met the league 's eligibility requirements .
topic_chat_response: yeah i guess so . did you know women can play too ?
